jed

Class DiagonalBandwidthSelector2d

  • java.lang.Object
    • jed.DiagonalBandwidthSelector2d

  • public class DiagonalBandwidthSelector2d
extends java.lang.Object
    So you've got some 2d points and you want to convolve them with a gaussian kernel to generate a pdf. What bandwidth of kernel do you use? Well, there's some criteria, like MSIE or some such, that you should usually try to minimize. That is what this class does. Give it some points and it will give you the optimal kernel bandwidth.

    Currently limited to diagonal bandwidth matrices (Gaussians that are symmetric about each axis).

    This is based on matlab code by Zdravko Botev:

    Z. I. Botev, J. F. Grotowski and D. P. Kroese "KERNEL DENSITY ESTIMATION VIA DIFFUSION", Submitted to the Annals of Statistics, 2009

    Author:
    Philip DeCamp

      • computeBandwidth

                                        int off,

        Throws:

      • computeBandwidth

        public static double[] computeBandwidth(double[] points,
                                        int off,
                                        int numPoints,
                                        double[] bounds,
                                        int quant)
                                 throws MathException
        Parameters:
        points - Set of 2d points, closely packed: [x0,y0,x1,y1...]. points.length > off + numPoints * 2
        off - Offset into points array.
        numPoints - Number of points.
        bounds - A length-4 array containing the bounds [x0,y0,x1,y1] of the region of interest. [Optional]
        quant - Determines level of quantization of point positions. Default is 256.
        Returns:
        A 2x2 matrix, [exx, exy; exy, eyy] containing the bandwidth matrix. Will always be diagonal.
        Throws:
        MathException - If method fails to estimate optimal bandwidth.

      • get_Bandwidths

        public static double[] get_Bandwidths()
